body.p: This document provides an overview of the known issues and workarounds for Release Candidate 1.
Preliminary release notes for are available here.

section.title: Multipath Boot from SAN
section.p: The installation instructions for Multipath Boot from SAN are available here.
section.note: Multipath Boot from SAN is not supported on "native" FCoE. Also, only LUNs that are fully provisioned at the backend are supported. Some issues have been seen with Qlogic FC configurations and these are currently being investigated. It is not recommended to use this configuration in RC1. (HLX-1762)

section.title: RHEL Compute Nodes
section.note: For Release Candidate 1, the deployer cannot install RHEL nodes on UEFI - only legacy BIOS is supported (HLM-3424).
section.p: For information on deploying RHEL Compute Nodes see here.

section.title: Upgrade is Broken
section.p: It is not possible to upgrade from 2.1.* to Release Candidate 1.

section.title: Other Know Issues in Release Candidate 1

ul.li: Multiple attach/detach operations to a RHEL compute instance can lead to failed subsequent attaches (CINDER-451)
Intermittent kernel crashes on contoller nodes (HLX-1748)
Horizon UI error messages cannot be seesn as they are displayed in white text on a white background (HORI-5330)

section.title: Fixing Logrotate After Running Out Of Disk Space
section.p: Improvements to the log rotation process provides more frequent checks to automatically to warn customers if they are close to using 100% of the disk space. However, if a customer does run out of disk space on /var/log, then logrotate will start creating empty .1 files. These files will not be compressed because there is no more disk space. Freeing disk space will not fix logrotate. To fix logrotate, you will need to either compress all the *.l log files, or remove them.
section.note: Currently there are no plans to fix this because the improvements to the log rotation process make it less likely to run out of disk space. The improvements include running a check on disk space every 5 minutes (instead of once an hour in Helion OpenStack 2.0), and when it gets close to full (default value is 95%), running logrotate.
